ras_commander.RasHdf module

RasHdf Module

This module provides utilities for working with RESULTS (Plan) HDF files in HEC-RAS projects. It contains the RasHdf class, which offers various static methods for extracting, analyzing, and manipulating data from HEC-RAS RESULTS HDF files.

Note

This method is decorated with @hdf_operation, which handles the opening and closing of the HDF file. The decorator should be used for all methods that directly interact with HDF files. It ensures proper file handling and error management.

When using the @hdf_operation decorator: - The method receives an open h5py.File object as its first argument after ‘cls’. - Error handling for file operations is managed by the decorator. - The HDF file is automatically closed after the method execution.

Methods without this decorator must manually handle file opening, closing, and error management. Failure to use the decorator or properly manage the file can lead to resource leaks or file access errors.

Example

@classmethod @hdf_operation def example_method(cls, hdf_file: h5py.File, other_args):

# Method implementation using hdf_file

This module is part of the ras-commander library and uses a centralized logging configuration.

Logging Configuration: - The logging is set up in the logging_config.py file. - A @log_call decorator is available to automatically log function calls. - Log levels: DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR, CRITICAL - Logs are written to both console and a rotating file handler. - The default log file is ‘ras_commander.log’ in the ‘logs’ directory. - The default log level is INFO.

To use logging in this module: 1. Use the @log_call decorator for automatic function call logging. 2. For additional logging, use logger.[level]() calls (e.g., logger.info(), logger.debug()). 3. Obtain the logger using: logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

Example

@log_call def my_function():

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__) logger.debug(“Additional debug information”) # Function logic here

class ras_commander.RasHdf.RasHdf[source]

Bases: object

A utility class for working with HDF files in HEC-RAS projects.

This class provides static methods for various operations on HDF files, including listing paths, extracting data, and performing analyses on HEC-RAS project data stored in HDF format.

static hdf_operation(func)[source]

A decorator for HDF file operations in the RasHdf class.

This decorator wraps methods that perform operations on HDF files. It handles: 1. Resolving the HDF filename from various input types. 2. Opening and closing the HDF file. 3. Error handling and logging. 4. Applying the decorated function as a class method.

Parameters:

func (Callable) – The function to be decorated.

Returns:

A wrapped version of the input function as a class method.

Return type:

Callable

Raises:

ValueError – If the HDF file is not found.

Usage:

@RasHdf.hdf_operation def some_hdf_method(cls, hdf_file, …):

# Method implementation

classmethod get_runtime_data(hdf_input, ras_object=None)[source]

Extract runtime and compute time data from a single HDF file.

Parameters:

  • hdf_input (Union[str, Path]) – The plan number or full path to the HDF file.

  • ras_object (RasPrj, optional) – The RAS project object. If None, uses the global ras instance.

Returns:

DataFrame containing runtime and compute time data, or None if data extraction fails.

Return type:

Optional[pd.DataFrame]

Example

>>> runtime_df = RasHdf.get_runtime_data("path/to/file.hdf")
>>> if runtime_df is not None:
...     print(runtime_df.head())
classmethod get_2d_flow_area_names(hdf_input, ras_object=None)[source]

List 2D Flow Area names from the HDF file.

Parameters:

  • hdf_input (Union[str, Path]) – The plan number or full path to the HDF file.

  • ras_object (RasPrj, optional) – The RAS project object. If None, uses the global ras instance.

Returns:

List of 2D Flow Area names, or None if no 2D Flow Areas are found.

Return type:

Optional[List[str]]

Raises:

ValueError – If no 2D Flow Areas are found in the HDF file.

classmethod get_polygon_info_and_parts(hdf_input, area_name=None, ras_object=None)[source]

Extract Polygon Info and Parts from the HDF file.

Parameters:

  • hdf_input (Union[str, Path]) – The plan number or full path to the HDF file.

  • area_name (Optional[str]) – Name of the 2D Flow Area to extract data from. If None, uses the first 2D Area Name found.

  • ras_object (RasPrj, optional) – The RAS project object. If None, uses the global ras instance.

Returns:

Two DataFrames containing Polygon Info and Polygon Parts respectively, or None for each if the corresponding data is not found.

Return type:

Tuple[Optional[pd.DataFrame], Optional[pd.DataFrame]]

Example

>>> polygon_info_df, polygon_parts_df = RasHdf.get_polygon_info_and_parts("path/to/file.hdf")
>>> if polygon_info_df is not None and polygon_parts_df is not None:
...     print("Polygon Info:")
...     print(polygon_info_df.head())
...     print("Polygon Parts:")
...     print(polygon_parts_df.head())
... else:
...     print("Polygon data not found")

classmethod get_cells_center_data(hdf_input, area_name=None, ras_object=None)[source]

Extract Cells Center Coordinates and Manning’s n from the HDF file.

Parameters:

  • hdf_input (Union[str, Path]) – The plan number or full path to the HDF file.

  • area_name (Optional[str]) – Name of the 2D Flow Area to extract data from. If None, uses the first 2D Area Name found.

  • ras_object (RasPrj, optional) – The RAS project object. If None, uses the global ras instance.

Returns:

Two DataFrames containing Cells Center Coordinates and Manning’s n respectively, or None for each if the corresponding data is not found.

Return type:

Tuple[Optional[pd.DataFrame], Optional[pd.DataFrame]]

Example

>>> coords_df, mannings_df = RasHdf.get_cells_center_data("path/to/file.hdf")
>>> if coords_df is not None and mannings_df is not None:
...     print("Cell Center Coordinates:")
...     print(coords_df.head())
...     print("Manning's n:")
...     print(mannings_df.head())
... else:
...     print("Cell center data not found")

Extract Faces Cell and FacePoint Indexes from the HDF file.

Parameters:

  • hdf_input (Union[str, Path]) – The plan number or full path to the HDF file.

  • area_name (Optional[str]) – Name of the 2D Flow Area to extract data from. If None, uses the first 2D Area Name found.

  • ras_object (RasPrj, optional) – The RAS project object. If None, uses the global ras instance.

Returns:

Two DataFrames containing Faces Cell Indexes and FacePoint Indexes respectively, or None for each if the corresponding data is not found.

Return type:

Tuple[Optional[pd.DataFrame], Optional[pd.DataFrame]]

Example

>>> cell_indexes_df, facepoint_indexes_df = RasHdf.get_faces_indexes("path/to/file.hdf")
>>> if cell_indexes_df is not None and facepoint_indexes_df is not None:
...     print("Faces Cell Indexes:")
...     print(cell_indexes_df.head())
...     print("Faces FacePoint Indexes:")
...     print(facepoint_indexes_df.head())
... else:
...     print("Faces indexes data not found")

classmethod get_faces_perimeter_data(hdf_input, area_name=None, ras_object=None)[source]

Extract Faces Perimeter Info and Values from the HDF file.

Parameters:

  • hdf_input (Union[str, Path]) – The plan number or full path to the HDF file.

  • area_name (Optional[str]) – Name of the 2D Flow Area to extract data from. If None, uses the first 2D Area Name found.

  • ras_object (RasPrj, optional) – The RAS project object. If None, uses the global ras instance.

Returns:

DataFrames containing Faces Perimeter Info and Values.

Return type:

Tuple[Optional[pd.DataFrame], Optional[pd.DataFrame]]

Raises:

  • ValueError – If no HDF file is found for the given plan number.

  • FileNotFoundError – If the specified HDF file does not exist.

Example

>>> perimeter_info_df, perimeter_values_df = RasHdf.get_faces_perimeter_data("path/to/file.hdf")
>>> if perimeter_info_df is not None and perimeter_values_df is not None:
...     print("Perimeter Info:")
...     print(perimeter_info_df.head())
...     print("Perimeter Values:")
...     print(perimeter_values_df.head())
... else:
...     print("Perimeter data not found")
